Award.AwardTitle: Electro-Optics of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube Thin Films: Physics and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract - Electro-Optics of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube Thin Films: Physics and Applications.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Individual semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotubes (SC-SWNTs) constitute the ideal field effect transistor as a result of their high mobilities, high current carrying capacity and low intrinsic capacitance. The development of devices based on a channel composed of a single semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotube continues to be an active area of research due to the stringent requirements that this technology places on the material purity of the SC-SWNTs (diameter, chirality and the necessity to exclude metallic SWNTs), and assembly of individual devices into fully wired very large scale integrated (VLSI) circuits. In this respect the SC-SWNT films proposed for study in the present project form a particularly appealing target because such films are readily prepared by simple bench top laboratory techniques that include filtration, spraying, drop-casting and stamping and by careful control of the preparative conditions, readily allow the reproducible fabrication of flexible, transferrable SC-SWNT films with thicknesses that range from 1 to 1000 nm.

The present proposal aims to further this thin film technology by extending the outstanding engineering and physical properties of single SC-SWNT devices to chemically engineered SWNT thin films by use of suitably chosen organic dopants and ionic liquids in gated field effect transistor devices. Among the functional optoelectronic components selected for study are electro-optical modulators, photodetectors and light emitters. The experimental observation of the enhanced Franz-Keldysh effect may lead to a new generation of electro-optical modulators capable of operating at high speed, high efficiency and low voltage. The new strategy of p-n junction formation, based on the recent observation of strong internal electric fields in SWNT thin film channels coated with ionic liquids, will be used to enhance the photoconductivity in SWNTs. In past flexible electronics and smart window applications, SWNT thin films were usually explored as passive transparent electrodes; this proposal will explore the feasibility of utilizing SWNT thin films as active electrochromic layers for smart windows and electrically configurable optical media. The proposed work will stimulate the development of a new field of optoelectronics based on SWNT thin films and thin film based flexible electronics which will increase the technological and economic competitiveness of the United States.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
It is proposed to experimentally explore the physics of electro-optical phenomena in films of semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotubes (SC-SWNTs) and their device applications. The SWNT thin films constitute the ideal medium for studying electro-optical phenomena, because they possess the same fundamental physical properties as individual SWNTs, but also allow the application of a variety of characterization techniques and offer the possibility of the development of a new class of SWNT thin film based electro-optical devices. The project focuses on the application of semiconducting SWNTs and the work builds on recent developments in this area such as the SWNT bolometric photodetector, optocoupler, electro-optical modulator and electrically reconfigurable optical media. Proposed new experiments include: (i) the realization of the enhanced Franz-Keldysh effect by the application of strong longitudinal electric fields to films of aligned SWNTs; (ii) the fabrication of SWNT p-n junctions utilizing electrostatic doping induced by an ionic liquid for the development of photodetectors and light emitters; (iii) exploration of the ability of SWNT thin films to function as electrically configurable optical media of spatially modulated infrared transparency and as the active electrochromic layer for smart windows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project is to experimentally explore the physics of electro-optical phenomena in films of semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotubes (SC-SWNTs) and their device applications. The following specific directions have been explored:

Fast Electrochromic Device Based on Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube Thin Films: We have developed fast electrochromic device based on SWNT thin films with the active electrochromic layer made of a film of SC-SWNTs and the counter-electrode composed of a film of metallic (MT-) SWNTs in which transparency is controlled by ionic liquid gating. The response time of the device of 1 millisecond is thousands times faster than of typical electrolyte-controlled devices. In our initial efforts it was found that achieving a high modulation depth requires an increasing thickness of the electrochromically active SC-SWNT layer resulting in a slowdown of the switching time by more than order of magnitude. In our later development we restored the milliseconds range switching time by the counter-intuitive action of increasing the thickness of the MT-SWNT layer thus matching the electrochemical capacitances of the two sides of the electrochromic cell. As a result, a high modulation depth of 20 dB and high coloration efficiency exceeding 1800 cm2/C at an infrared wavelength of 1770 nm were achieved. The development of fast electrochromic systems provides an opportunity to expand the field of thin film SWNT optoelectronics into smart window applications, notch filters and modulators for fiber-optic communication, infrared imaging, artificial reconfigurable camouflage, and augmented reality systems. The operational wavelength can be modified by utilization of SWNTs of different diameters in order to cover the visible and near-infrared spectral ranges and expanded into the 8-14 micrometers long-wave infrared region.

Visible Blind UV Photodetector Based on Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube Thin Film - ZnO Vertical Heterostructure: UV photodetector based on a vertical heterojunction of thin film of p-SC-SWNTs and wide bandgap semiconductor n-ZnO was demonstrated. In this device architecture thin film of semiconducting SWNTs possesses multiple functions acting as p-type semiconductor and as transparent conducting electrode. The detector shows a high current rectification ratio of 1000, photoresponsivity exceeding 150 A/W in the UV spectral range, and a low dark current. The detector is visible blind with UV to visible light photoresponsivity ratio of 100 000 because of extremely short photocarrier lifetimes in the SWNTs due to strong electron-phonon interaction leading to excitons formation. In this vertical configuration, UV radiation penetrates the top semitransparent SC-SWNTs layer with low losses and excites photocarriers within n-ZnO layer in the close proximity to the p-SWNT/n-ZnO interface where electron-hole pairs are efficiently separated by high built-in electric field associated with the heterojunction. This development expands the scope of applications of SWNT thin films in the field of UV detection for civil and military needs such as UV level monitoring for public health, flame detection, inter-satellite communication, early warning missile detection and engine flame control.

Midgap states in semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotubes: The mechanism of the electrical transport leading to the unusually weak temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity of SC-SWNT networks has been analyzed.  Observed temperature dependence of the conductivity indicates the presence of midgap electronic states in the semiconducting SWNTs which provide a source of low-energy excitations which contributing to hopping conductance along the nanotubes followed by fluctuation induced tunneling across the inter-nanotube junctions. Midgap states are present in conventional semiconductors, but unusual here is the extent of their contribution to the electrical transport in the networks of semiconducting SWNTs. The progress of the semiconductor industry has been driven by the continuous improvement of materials purity, which in the case of silicon has been raised from 99.99% in the 1950s to its current level of more than 99.9999999%. The controlled introduction of impurities with energy states which lie within the bandgap of Si and Ge has allowed the exponential growth of the semiconductor industry. The current state of SWNT purity in the best separated materials is probably 99.99% to 99.999% (4N-5N) corresponding to one defect per 50 to 500 nm of the SWNT length and this obviously affects the applications of these materials. Understanding of the nature of midgap states in SC-SWNTs and their effect on the electronic properties of SC-SWNT networks is important for development of electronic and photonic applications of SC-SWNTs.

Human resources: Graduate and undergraduate students received an opportunity to work on the projects where material science, engineering, physics, chemistry and device preparation are combined in a single project. The project provided education and training to US Army veteran graduate student who defended his Ph.D. Thesis in 2016, and five other graduate and undergraduate students. In total, three graduate students received or will receive their PhD degrees by the end of 2018 on the basis of research conducted within this NSF funded project and will be joining United States workforces in science, technology and education.
